diagnostics.description: The HVAC system has an insufficient refrigerant charge, usually due to a leak or improper charging, resulting in less refrigerant than required.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: Cooling capacity drops, longer runtimes occur, coil may frost over, and the system struggles to reach set temperature.
common_root_causes: Refrigerant leak at coils or line joints
Incorrect charge during installation or service
Gradual leak over time reducing refrigerant level
canonical_symptoms: Poor cooling performance especially on hot days
Very long cooling cycles that never reach setpoint
Frost or ice visible on the indoor coil or suction line
technician_observation_phrases: low suction pressure and low superheat
bubbling sight glass indicating undercharge
oil staining on refrigerant lines or coils (leak evidence)
diagnostics.notes: Often described as 'low on Freon'. Technicians will verify by pressure readings and may find a leak that needs repair before recharging.
evidence_snippets: Refrigerant leaks compromise your HVAC’s efficiency or cooling capacity. Typical signs of this are higher-than-usual energy bills or poor temperature control. Sometimes, you might even see ice forming on the coils:contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}.

diagnostics.description: The system contains too much refrigerant (overcharged), which can lead to abnormally high pressures and reduced efficiency.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: Cooling efficiency is reduced, and the compressor may run hot or cycle off on high pressure limits; cooling output may drop.
common_root_causes: Service overcharge (too much refrigerant added)
Incorrect factory charge or improper charging procedure
Mixing of incompatible refrigerants or oils
canonical_symptoms: Elevated energy consumption
Compressor running but poor cooling
High discharge air temperature from outdoor unit
technician_observation_phrases: high head pressure and low subcooling
compressor amperage higher than normal
high pressure cut-out trips
diagnostics.notes: Overcharge can cause liquid refrigerant to flood the compressor, potentially damaging it. It often results from uncalibrated charging methods.
evidence_snippets: Sub-optimal refrigerant charge. Inappropriate refrigerant charge is one of the most common faults in rooftop air conditioners... low and high refrigerant charge result in decreased efficiency:contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}.

diagnostics.specific_diagnostic_name: Air or moisture in refrigerant system
diagnostics.description: Non-condensable gases (air) or moisture are present in the refrigerant loop, degrading heat transfer and causing abnormal pressures.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The system operates inefficiently with elevated head pressure and temperature; can lead to icing at the expansion device or internal corrosion.
common_root_causes: Poor evacuation during installation or service
Refrigerant leak allowing air ingress before repair
Moisture due to failing to replace filter-drier or fix leaks
canonical_symptoms: Reduced cooling capacity despite correct charge level
Occasional ice or frost at expansion valve area
Unusually high compressor discharge pressure
technician_observation_phrases: unstable pressure readings (fluctuating high side)
hissing or gurgling in system from vapor in lines
acid test failure indicating moisture presence
diagnostics.notes: Air in the system can cause pressure spikes and inefficiency, while moisture can freeze at the TXV and cause intermittent blockages. Proper evacuation and dryer replacement are essential.
evidence_snippets: When non-condensable contaminants such as air and water vapor are introduced into a refrigerant circuit, the system operates less efficiently because heat transfer surface is reduced, and compression power increases:contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}.

diagnostics.description: There is an obstruction in the refrigerant line (often in the filter-drier or a clogged capillary tube) that impedes refrigerant flow.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: System pressures are abnormal (often low low-side pressure). Cooling capacity drops significantly as refrigerant cannot circulate properly; the evaporator may starve and even freeze up.
common_root_causes: Clogged filter/drier (debris or moisture turned to ice)
Blocked capillary tube or TXV inlet screen
Solder or metal shavings lodged in lines
canonical_symptoms: Evaporator coil freezes or ices up due to starvation
Poor cooling and low suction pressure observed
Compressor runs hot as it works against restriction
technician_observation_phrases: large pressure drop across filter-drier
high superheat with low suction pressure
frost line beginning at point of restriction
diagnostics.notes: Any restriction forces the compressor to work harder and reduces refrigerant flow. Techs often find a temperature drop or frost at the blockage point (for example, a cold spot on the liquid line).
evidence_snippets: Flow constriction due to blockage in the refrigerant line... starves flow to system components. This causes reduced cooling capacity as refrigerant flow is reduced, and increases compressor power... When a restriction is present in the liquid line... may cause freezing on the evaporator coil:contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}.

diagnostics.description: The thermostatic expansion valve (TXV) or other metering device is not functioning correctly, causing improper refrigerant flow into the evaporator.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: If the valve is stuck closed or restricted, the evaporator is starved (low evaporator pressure, poor cooling, possible icing). If stuck open, the evaporator floods (very low superheat, risk of compressor liquid slugging).
common_root_causes: TXV sensing bulb lost charge or mis-mounted
Debris or wax plugging the TXV orifice
Capillary tube system clogged or mismatched
canonical_symptoms: AC not cooling well despite correct charge
Evaporator coil may freeze (if underfeeding)
Compressor may shut off on protection (if overfeeding liquid)
technician_observation_phrases: abnormal superheat (either too high or near zero)
TXV hunting or unresponsive to load changes
temperature difference across expansion device
diagnostics.notes: A faulty TXV often mimics symptoms of incorrect refrigerant charge. Technicians will differentiate by checking subcooling and superheat. In some cases, a manual bypass or TXV replacement is needed.
evidence_snippets: These restrictions can be caused by... fouled expansion devices, dirty liquid line filter/dryers... liquid line restriction can reduce EER by 56%:contentReference[oaicite:4]{index=4}.

diagnostics.description: In a heat pump system, the reversing valve is failing to switch refrigerant flow correctly between heating and cooling mode. It may be stuck in one position or leaking internally.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The heat pump may become locked in one mode (cooling or heating only). In cooling season, it might blow warm air; in heating season, it might blow cool air. Efficiency drops and desired mode cannot be achieved.
common_root_causes: Valve solenoid coil failure (not shifting valve)
Mechanical internal failure or debris in valve
Valve body leak causing partial bypass
canonical_symptoms: Heat pump stuck on cooling mode in winter (no heat)
System cools in cooling mode but not heating in heat mode (or vice versa)
Hissing or whistling sound near reversing valve assembly
technician_observation_phrases: no pressure differential change when switching modes
valve energized but refrigerant flow not redirecting
gauges show abnormal pressures for given mode
diagnostics.notes: A malfunctioning reversing valve can sometimes be identified by tapping it gently (a temporary fix if stuck). Replacement is often needed if the valve is physically stuck or leaking internally.
evidence_snippets: There are several indications that there may be a problem with your heat pump reversing valve... What to look for: * Heat pump not heating * The heat pump not cooling * The unit is stuck in one mode:contentReference[oaicite:5]{index=5}.

diagnostics.specific_diagnostic_name: Compressor will not start (locked or hard start)
diagnostics.description: The AC compressor is failing to start running. It may be "locked up" mechanically or unable to overcome starting torque due to electrical issues.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: Little or no cooling is produced because the compressor is not running. The outdoor unit may hum or click repeatedly. The system may trip breakers if the compressor draws locked-rotor current.
common_root_causes: Failed start capacitor or relay
Seized compressor (mechanical lockup)
Low supply voltage or voltage imbalance (for 3-phase units)
canonical_symptoms: Outdoor unit hums but compressor does not run
AC blows room-temperature air (no cooling) even though fans run
Circuit breaker trips when AC tries to start
technician_observation_phrases: high amperage draw at compressor start (LRA)
compressor body overheats without running
burnt wires or terminals at compressor
diagnostics.notes: Technicians may attempt a hard-start kit if the compressor is hard to start. If the compressor is mechanically locked, replacement is usually required. Always ensure supply voltage and capacitors are correct first.
evidence_snippets: If it’s malfunctioning, it will not cool the air properly:contentReference[oaicite:6]{index=6}. (In context: a malfunctioning compressor fails to compress refrigerant, resulting in no cooling.)
A common problem is the circuit breaker switching on and off... Locate your electrical panel and check the AC switch. If it is in the “OFF” position, reset it:contentReference[oaicite:7]{index=7}.

diagnostics.description: The compressor's electric motor has failed, either by burning out (open winding) or shorting to ground. The compressor no longer operates or trips safety devices immediately.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: No cooling is delivered. Typically the system will trip the circuit breaker or blow fuses when the compressor attempts to start. In some cases, a burning electrical smell may be noticeable.
common_root_causes: Prolonged overheating of compressor (loss of cooling, low charge)
Electrical surge or run capacitor failure causing motor damage
Age and wear leading to insulation breakdown
canonical_symptoms: AC trips breaker immediately when it tries to cool
Burning or electrical smell from outdoor unit
Compressor does not run and may make no sound or a brief hum
technician_observation_phrases: compressor windings test open or grounded
burn marks around compressor terminals
acidic smell in oil (from burnout)
diagnostics.notes: A "burned out" compressor often contaminates the refrigerant with acid and carbon. Besides replacing the compressor, the system must be cleaned (flush, new filter-drier) to remove contaminants.
evidence_snippets: If the outdoor unit smells like burning, it could be the result of a failing capacitor, failing compressor, failing fan motor, or a combination of these things. Overheating components can give off a burning rubber or electrical smell:contentReference[oaicite:8]{index=8}.

diagnostics.specific_diagnostic_name: Compressor valves leaking or low compression
diagnostics.description: The internal valves or scroll elements of the compressor are worn or damaged, causing reduced refrigerant compression. The compressor runs but cannot build normal pressure.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: Cooling output is significantly reduced despite the compressor running. Suction pressure and discharge pressure may both be lower than normal, and the system struggles to cool effectively.
common_root_causes: Normal wear from long-term use (especially in older compressors)
Overheating or liquid slugging causing valve damage
Manufacturing defects leading to early wear
canonical_symptoms: Poor cooling even though compressor and fans are running continuously
Little difference between suction and discharge pressures (low compression)
High utility bills as system runs constantly without reaching setpoint
technician_observation_phrases: suction pressure higher than expected (lack of drop)
compressor amp draw lower than normal (not doing work)
compressor sounds unusually quiet or unloads
diagnostics.notes: Leaky compressor valves mean the compressor cannot achieve the necessary pressure differential. It's often diagnosed by measuring pressures and performing a pump-down test. The remedy is typically compressor replacement.
evidence_snippets: Typical issues include things like heat pump charging problems, condenser faults, and dirty or blocked lines:contentReference[oaicite:9]{index=9}. (Here 'condenser faults' can encompass internal compressor problems that reduce cooling.)

diagnostics.description: The HVAC system’s air filter is dirty or clogged with dust, severely restricting the airflow through the indoor unit.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: Reduced airflow leads to inadequate cooling or heating distribution. The evaporator coil can get too cold and potentially freeze due to low airflow. The furnace may overheat and cycle off on high limit.
common_root_causes: Filter not changed frequently enough
Heavy dust or construction debris in home
Intake vents blocked causing filter to load quickly
canonical_symptoms: Weak airflow from vents
Some rooms never get cool or warm enough
Indoor unit or ducts make whistling noises (due to high static pressure)
technician_observation_phrases: filter media visibly coated with dust
low airflow noted across coil, high temperature rise in furnace
evaporator coil freezing due to starvation
diagnostics.notes: This is one of the most common and easily solved issues. Regular filter maintenance can prevent a host of other problems. In many cases, simply replacing the filter restores proper airflow.
evidence_snippets: A dirty or clogged air filter will restrict the airflow and put extra strain on your system. A very dirty or misplaced air filter could restrict airflow so much that the fan continues to run but no cool air comes out of the vents:contentReference[oaicite:10]{index=10}.

diagnostics.description: The indoor evaporator coil is coated with dust, dirt, or biological growth, impeding air passage and heat transfer.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: Cooling efficiency drops and airflow is reduced. The coil may not absorb enough heat, potentially causing it to ice over. Humidity removal also worsens due to reduced coil surface exposure.
common_root_causes: Prolonged operation with dirty filter (allowing dust through)
Moist coil capturing dust and growing mold
Smoking or heavy indoor air pollutants clogging coil fins
canonical_symptoms: Reduced airflow even with a clean filter
Musty odors when AC runs (from mold on coil)
AC struggles to cool adequately despite compressor running
technician_observation_phrases: coil fins visibly matted with dirt or biofilm
lower than expected evaporator temperature (risk of freeze)
uneven temperature drop across coil
diagnostics.notes: A dirty evaporator coil not only chokes airflow but also insulates the coil from the air. Professional cleaning may be required if buildup is substantial. Coil fouling can also lead to condensate drainage issues due to slime.
evidence_snippets: Coils can become dirty from dust in the air... which can make the unit not work properly:contentReference[oaicite:11]{index=11}.

diagnostics.specific_diagnostic_name: Blower fan motor failed or not running
diagnostics.description: The indoor blower fan motor has malfunctioned or stopped working, so the indoor unit cannot circulate air through the ducts.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: Little to no air comes out of supply vents. Cooling or heating may occur at the coil, but without airflow the conditioned air doesn’t reach the rooms. The system may overheat or the coil may freeze due to lack of air movement.
common_root_causes: Motor burnout due to age or overheating
Motor bearings seized up (mechanical failure)
Electrical open or short in motor windings
canonical_symptoms: No air blows from vents even though the system is on
Unusual buzzing or humming from furnace/air handler with no fan movement
Burning smell from the air handler (motor overheating)
technician_observation_phrases: blower wheel not turning when it should
high current draw or no continuity through motor windings
capacitor is good but motor won’t start
diagnostics.notes: Sometimes a failing blower motor will give warnings like screeching (bearing noise) or intermittent operation before failing completely. Replacement of the motor (and capacitor, if applicable) is the typical remedy.
evidence_snippets: If it’s not working correctly, you’ll notice poor airflow or a blower that won’t turn on at all, leaving your house feeling cold and uncomfortable:contentReference[oaicite:12]{index=12}.
Symptoms of a failing blower motor include hearing the outdoor air conditioning unit running, but no sound or airflow from the indoor system:contentReference[oaicite:13]{index=13}.

diagnostics.description: The run or start capacitor for the indoor blower motor has failed, preventing the blower motor from starting or running properly.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The indoor fan may fail to start (no airflow), or it may start slowly and run weakly. Often a failing capacitor causes a humming sound as the motor struggles to turn.
common_root_causes: Electrical breakdown of capacitor due to age/heat
Power surge damaging the capacitor
Prolonged motor operation stressing the capacitor
canonical_symptoms: Blower fan does not come on, though other parts of system run
Humming or clicking noise from furnace/air handler when fan should start
Sometimes fan can be kick-started manually (spins when pushed, indicating bad cap)
technician_observation_phrases: capacitor bulging or leaking dielectric fluid
measured capacitance far below rating
motor runs when a known-good capacitor is substituted
diagnostics.notes: A bad blower capacitor is a frequent cause of "no airflow" complaints. Technicians will test the capacitance or simply replace the cap if suspect. It’s a relatively quick and inexpensive repair.
evidence_snippets: If the heat pump is not turning on, it could be a bad capacitor to blame:contentReference[oaicite:14]{index=14}. (Heat pump context, but similarly a bad capacitor can prevent a blower from turning on.)

diagnostics.description: Airflow back to the HVAC system is impeded due to blocked return grilles or undersized/closed return ducts, reducing the total air the system can circulate.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The system experiences reduced airflow and may run with lower efficiency. In extreme cases, similar to a dirty filter, the coil can freeze (in cooling) or the furnace can overheat due to the air starvation.
common_root_causes: Furniture or objects covering return vents
Closed doors in a central return system causing pressure issues
Ductwork design with insufficient return sizing
canonical_symptoms: Weak airflow throughout the house, not just at one vent
Whistling or high-pitched sound around return grills (as air is starved)
Hot and cold spots due to improper circulation
technician_observation_phrases: return plenum pressure extremely low (high static)
inlet grill blocked by dust buildup or obstruction
improved airflow when return grill or door is opened
diagnostics.notes: Homeowners sometimes inadvertently block returns with furniture or rugs. Ensuring all return vents are clear and open can often remedy this without any technical service.
evidence_snippets: The air handler might also not be working because of a blown fuse or open circuit breaker... You should also check return grills for blockages that could keep air from circulating freely in the system:contentReference[oaicite:15]{index=15}.

diagnostics.description: The outdoor condenser coil is coated or blocked with dirt, dust, leaves, or other debris, hindering heat transfer and airflow.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: Heat cannot be rejected efficiently. Head pressures rise, compressor runs hotter, and cooling capacity falls. On a hot day, the system may struggle to cool and can even shut off on high pressure safety.
common_root_causes: Lack of regular outdoor unit cleaning
Debris like grass clippings, cottonwood seeds clogging coil fins
Nearby dryer vent lint accumulating on coil
canonical_symptoms: AC cools poorly especially in very hot weather
Outdoor unit expels very hot air and possibly trips on high pressure
Higher electrical bills due to reduced efficiency
technician_observation_phrases: condenser fins matted with dirt or lint
refrigerant pressures abnormally high
compressor amperage elevated due to heat load
diagnostics.notes: Condenser coil cleaning is a standard maintenance item. Even a thin layer of dirt on coil fins can significantly degrade performance. Spraying the coil with water (with power off) or using coil cleaner can restore operation.
evidence_snippets: Debris can easily stick to the inlet side of the cooling coil in your unit. Be sure to clear away any tall grass, sticks, or leaves that may be surrounding your outdoor unit:contentReference[oaicite:16]{index=16}.

diagnostics.description: The outdoor condenser fan is not working (motor failed or fan stuck), so the outdoor coil is not receiving adequate airflow for heat rejection.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: Without the condenser fan, high-side (head) pressure skyrockets because the heat in refrigerant is not removed. The AC may blow warm air and the compressor can overheat or trip off on high pressure limits quickly.
common_root_causes: Fan motor burnout or seized bearings
Wiring issue or failed contactor to fan motor
Fan blade jammed by debris or bent into shroud
canonical_symptoms: Outdoor fan not spinning even though AC is on (compressor may be humming or running hot)
AC quickly shuts off and on (high pressure safety cycling)
Warm air or no cooling inside the home
technician_observation_phrases: outdoor fan blade can be spun freely (motor not energized)
voltage present at fan motor terminals but no rotation
motor windings test open or grounded
diagnostics.notes: Often accompanied by a humming noise from the outdoor unit as the compressor struggles without cooling air. This condition can quickly damage the compressor, so most systems have safety controls to shut it down.
evidence_snippets: If the unit is running but the heat pump fan isn’t spinning... Remember we said the capacitor helps power the compressor motor and the fan motor? This issue could be due to several reasons, including the capacitor:contentReference[oaicite:17]{index=17}.

diagnostics.description: The capacitor responsible for starting or running the outdoor fan motor has failed, resulting in the fan not starting or running weakly.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The condenser fan may not spin at all or only spin slowly, leading to inadequate cooling of the condenser coil. This causes rising head pressures and poor cooling; the compressor may cycle off on safety limits if it overheats.
common_root_causes: Electrical failure of capacitor due to age and heat
Power surge or lightning strike damaging the capacitor
Fan motor issues causing capacitor strain
canonical_symptoms: Outdoor fan does not run, though compressor might be running (you hear the compressor humming)
A buzzing sound from outdoor unit with fan stationary
Sometimes fan blades start if pushed manually (not safe to attempt, but indicative of bad cap)
technician_observation_phrases: capacitance test shows far below rated µF
capacitor casing is swollen or leaking
fan motor draws high current trying to start
diagnostics.notes: This is a very common AC issue. A technician will usually check the dual-run capacitor whenever an outdoor fan or compressor won't start, as it's often the culprit. Replacing the capacitor is typically a quick fix.
evidence_snippets: If the heat pump is not turning on (fan not turning), it could be a bad capacitor to blame... If you hear the capacitor clicking every few seconds, it is trying to release energy to start the motor:contentReference[oaicite:18]{index=18}.

diagnostics.description: The condenser (outdoor unit) is not receiving enough airflow. This could be due to a partially blocked coil, a weak fan, or recirculation of hot air around the unit.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: High pressure in the refrigerant circuit and reduced cooling capacity. The AC may blow warmer air and the compressor runs at higher temperature, potentially tripping on high-pressure or thermal limits.
common_root_causes: Partial debris blockage on condenser coil
Condenser fan motor running below speed or intermittently
Outdoor unit placed in confined area causing hot air recirculation
canonical_symptoms: AC blowing cooler than room temperature air but not cold enough
Outdoor unit expelling very little air or very hot air
System performance drops especially on hot days
technician_observation_phrases: moderately high head pressure with normal charge
condenser fan amp draw lower than spec (weak fan)
improvement when debris removed or unit is shaded
diagnostics.notes: This is a general category capturing any issue that leads to inadequate airflow through the condenser. It might be an early stage of coil dirt buildup or a fan starting to fail. Regular maintenance can prevent it from worsening.
evidence_snippets: One issue could be a blocked or clogged condenser coil... If you suspect the condenser unit is blocked, contact a professional technician to have them professionally clean the coil. The AC fan may also be to blame:contentReference[oaicite:19]{index=19}.

diagnostics.description: The thermostat is not set correctly for the desired operation: it may be turned off, set to the wrong mode (heat vs cool), have the fan set incorrectly, or programmed schedule not calling for conditioning when expected.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The HVAC system does not run in the intended mode. For example, cooling might not come on because the thermostat is set to heat or off, or the fan might run continuously if set to ON. Essentially, there is no fault in equipment, just in settings.
common_root_causes: User error in thermostat mode selection
Programmable thermostat schedule set incorrectly
Accidental setting change or thermostat UI confusion
canonical_symptoms: AC never starts cooling because thermostat was in heat mode
Furnace doesn’t fire because thermostat is set to off or cooling
Fan runs continuously (blowing room temp air) due to fan setting at ON
technician_observation_phrases: thermostat mode found set opposite of desired
thermostat setpoint higher than room temperature in cooling (therefore not calling)
schedule had setback preventing system operation at that time
diagnostics.notes: This is often the first thing a technician or homeowner should check. Many "no cooling" calls turn out to be thermostat set to the wrong mode or temperature. It’s a quick fix by adjusting settings.
evidence_snippets: The thermostat controls may be set incorrectly... Try turning the thermostat off and then on again. Reset to the desired temperature and see if that helps:contentReference[oaicite:20]{index=20}:contentReference[oaicite:21]{index=21}.

diagnostics.description: The thermostat has lost power (display is blank or unresponsive), so it cannot call for heating or cooling. This could be due to dead batteries or loss of 24V supply from the HVAC system.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The HVAC system will not turn on at all because it never receives a signal to run. All conditioning functions remain off until thermostat power is restored.
common_root_causes: Batteries in thermostat depleted (for battery-powered models)
Tripped low-voltage fuse or transformer issue cutting 24V power
Thermostat wiring disconnection (no power feed)
canonical_symptoms: Thermostat display is blank or unlit
HVAC does nothing when adjusting thermostat
No fan or system activity at any thermostat setting
technician_observation_phrases: no 24V at thermostat R terminal
HVAC control fuse blown, cutting power to stat
corroded battery terminals in thermostat
diagnostics.notes: If the thermostat is battery-operated, simply replacing the batteries may fix the issue. If it’s powered by the HVAC system (common wire), a blown fuse or transformer at the furnace could be the cause.
evidence_snippets: Check your thermostat to see if it is off or showing a blank display. If it is, try to switch it on. If the thermostat does not turn on, it could also have dead batteries:contentReference[oaicite:22]{index=22}.

diagnostics.specific_diagnostic_name: Thermostat sensor miscalibrated or bad location
diagnostics.description: The thermostat is reading the temperature inaccurately or is installed in a poor location (e.g., in direct sunlight or near a supply vent), causing improper system cycling.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The HVAC may short-cycle or run too long. The space might be too hot or too cold because the thermostat’s sense of room temperature is off. Comfort is inconsistent and system cycles at wrong times.
common_root_causes: Thermostat internal sensor drift (age or defect)
Thermostat mounted on an exterior wall or in sunlight, skewing its reading
Thermostat near a supply register or heat source (computers, etc.)
canonical_symptoms: Thermostat set to 72 but room feels much warmer or colder than that
HVAC turns on/off at odd times not matching actual room needs
Large temperature swings or uneven comfort in the area
technician_observation_phrases: thermostat reading deviates from actual room temp by several degrees
temperature sensor bias present compared to reference thermometer
improvement when thermostat location is bypassed or adjusted
diagnostics.notes: Calibration issues can sometimes be offset by adjustments in advanced thermostat settings (if available) or simply require relocating the thermostat to a representative location in the home.
evidence_snippets: Sometimes the issue isn’t with the furnace itself, but with the thermostat that’s controlling it. Dirty sensors, loose wires, or dead batteries are all potential causes of a malfunctioning thermostat that can cause your furnace to work intermittently or not at all:contentReference[oaicite:23]{index=23}.

diagnostics.description: The low-voltage wiring between the thermostat and HVAC equipment is incorrect, loose, or shorted, leading to improper control signals or no signals at all.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The system may not respond to thermostat settings. Examples: AC and heat might run simultaneously (if wires short), or nothing happens when calling for heat/cool (open circuit). Intermittent operation can occur if connections are loose.
common_root_causes: Thermostat wire connected to wrong terminals (mislabeling)
Loose terminal screws or wire splices
Short in thermostat cable (e.g., from nail through wire or rodent damage)
canonical_symptoms: HVAC does not turn on in the mode selected, or turns on the wrong function
Intermittent HVAC operation when jiggling the thermostat or wires
Thermostat appears to function but HVAC stays off (no signal reaching unit)
technician_observation_phrases: 24V common and call wires shorted causing no output
incorrect jumper or missing jumper on thermostat terminals
voltage present on control board inputs at wrong times
diagnostics.notes: Wiring issues often occur after a thermostat replacement or renovation that disturbed the cabling. A careful trace of each wire to its proper terminal (R, C, Y, W, G, etc.) is needed to fix miswiring.
evidence_snippets: Electrical issues are usually caused by problems such as burned-out circuit boards, defective wiring, or a malfunctioning thermostat. These issues can lead to system failure or intermittent performance problems:contentReference[oaicite:24]{index=24}.

diagnostics.description: The electronic control board (or control module) of the HVAC system is failing or has failed, leading to improper or no coordination of system components.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The system may behave erratically or not run at all. Furnace control board failure can prevent ignition or blower operation; an AC control board issue might stop the contactor or fan relays from energizing. In some cases, only certain functions fail (e.g., blower runs continuously or not at all).
common_root_causes: Voltage surges or lightning strike damaging circuitry
Overheating or moisture on the board causing solder joint failures
Age-related electronic component failure
canonical_symptoms: HVAC system is completely unresponsive even with correct thermostat signals
Certain cycles (like furnace ignition sequence) cut out prematurely or erratically
Visible burn marks on control board or smell of burnt electronics
technician_observation_phrases: no output from control board despite proper inputs (e.g., 24V present)
error codes or LEDs on board indicate internal fault
relay clicks missing or stuck on control board
diagnostics.notes: Many modern systems will display error codes if the control board detects a fault in itself or major components. Replacement of the board is often necessary if power cycling does not reset it.
evidence_snippets: Electrical issues are usually caused by problems such as burned-out circuit boards, defective wiring, or a malfunctioning thermostat:contentReference[oaicite:25]{index=25}.

diagnostics.description: In systems with communicating thermostats or networked controllers, a communication fault has occurred. The indoor and outdoor units (or other components) are not exchanging data or signals properly.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The system may shut down or revert to a default mode if communication is lost. Error codes often display. The HVAC might not turn on at all, or variable-speed components may run at fixed speeds due to lack of commands.
common_root_causes: Loose or broken communication wiring (e.g., RS485 bus in VRF)
Firmware/software glitch in control modules
Interference or noise on communication lines
canonical_symptoms: Thermostat or control panel shows a communication error code
System does not respond to thermostat changes in a communicating system
Outdoor unit runs but indoor unit doesn't (or vice versa) because commands aren't received
technician_observation_phrases: no voltage or signal on comm terminals where expected
error code like 'Comm Fault' or manufacturer-specific code
system works in emergency mode when communication is bypassed
diagnostics.notes: This issue is specific to newer systems that use digital communication instead of conventional on/off signals. Troubleshooting often involves checking wiring continuity and ensuring all controllers are powered and functioning.
evidence_snippets: Various faults can produce similar symptoms among different systems even in a specific HVAC system. (Communication errors often manifest as general non-operation, requiring specific diagnostic codes to identify.)

diagnostics.specific_diagnostic_name: No high-voltage power to HVAC unit
diagnostics.description: The HVAC system is not receiving high-voltage power. This could be due to a tripped circuit breaker, blown fuse, or an open disconnect switch, resulting in the entire unit being unpowered.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The system is completely non-functional: no blower, no compressor, no heating. The thermostat may be blank if it relies on transformer power from the unit. Essentially, the HVAC appears 'dead'.
common_root_causes: Tripped circuit breaker or blown fuse from overload or short
Service disconnect switch turned off (accidentally or for maintenance)
Power outage or no electrical service to circuit
canonical_symptoms: HVAC system does not turn on at all - no sound, no airflow
Thermostat might be blank (if no separate power source)
No response even when thermostat is adjusted
technician_observation_phrases: no voltage present at unit line terminals
breaker at panel found in tripped position
disconnect pull-out removed or breaker switch off at unit
diagnostics.notes: This is a basic but critical issue to check. Often homeowners discover the breaker was tripped due to a storm or overload. Resetting power may restore operation unless an underlying fault retrips it.
evidence_snippets: The most common cause of an air conditioner failing to turn on is a tripped circuit breaker:contentReference[oaicite:27]{index=27}.

diagnostics.specific_diagnostic_name: Emergency or service switch turned off
diagnostics.description: A manual power switch (such as a furnace emergency off switch or an outdoor disconnect) is in the off position, cutting power to the HVAC unit.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The equipment is completely off and unresponsive. This is often mistaken for a system failure when in fact it's just been manually switched off.
common_root_causes: Accidental switch off (someone turned off the furnace switch, often located on wall or unit)
Service left unit disconnected after maintenance
Safety switch triggered and needs reset (less common)
canonical_symptoms: No heating or cooling; system totally off
Fan doesn’t run even in ON mode
Upon inspection, switch found off
technician_observation_phrases: emergency cutoff switch at top of basement stairs is off
outdoor disconnect lever pulled out
voltage restored when switch toggled on
diagnostics.notes: This is essentially user error. It’s surprisingly common: e.g., a light switch in a closet actually controls the furnace power and gets turned off inadvertently. The fix is simply to restore the switch to ON.
evidence_snippets: Ensure no switches have tripped or fuses blown. If they have, fix them:contentReference[oaicite:28]{index=28}.

diagnostics.specific_diagnostic_name: Blown control fuse or transformer failure
diagnostics.description: The 24V control circuit is not powered due to a blown fuse on the control board or a failed control transformer. This cuts power to thermostats and relays, so the system does nothing.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The thermostat may be blank or display error, and the HVAC will not respond to any calls for heat/cool. No relays click, and no part of the system engages, even though main power is present.
common_root_causes: Short circuit in thermostat wiring (causing fuse to blow)
Contactors or valves coil short drawing too much current
Control transformer burned out by surge or overload
canonical_symptoms: System completely non-functional, yet breaker is fine (often thermostat blank)
Fuse on circuit board visibly blown (glass fuse filament broken or flag fuse LED lit)
No 24V present on any control terminals
technician_observation_phrases: 24VAC secondary shows 0V due to open fuse
primary voltage good but secondary transformer output missing
replacing 3A fuse restores operation until short reoccurs
diagnostics.notes: When a control fuse blows, it's important to find the cause (short) before replacing, otherwise the new fuse will also blow. Common culprits are shorted wires at the condenser contactor or at the thermostat.
evidence_snippets: A tripped circuit breaker or blown fuse can disrupt the flow of electricity to your furnace, preventing it from turning on:contentReference[oaicite:29]{index=29}.

diagnostics.description: A run or start capacitor for a major motor (compressor or fan) has failed. The motor may struggle to start or not run at all due to lack of phase shift and starting torque.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: If the compressor's capacitor fails, the compressor may not start - leading to no cooling and possibly just a humming noise. If a fan capacitor fails, that fan won’t start (e.g., condenser fan not spinning). The system’s performance is severely reduced or halted.
common_root_causes: High ambient temperatures degrading capacitor dielectric
Voltage spikes or surges damaging capacitor internally
Capacitor old age – capacitance drifted out of spec
canonical_symptoms: Outdoor unit hums but compressor and/or fan do not run
AC blows warm air because compressor isn’t running
Unit may intermittently start after many attempts (weak capacitor)
technician_observation_phrases: capacitor bulged or leaking oil
microfarad reading significantly below label value
motor starts immediately when capacitor is replaced
diagnostics.notes: Dual capacitors (which serve both compressor and fan) are common in outdoor units, and a failure can affect one or both functions. Proactively replacing an aging capacitor can prevent an unexpected AC outage.
evidence_snippets: If you hear the capacitor clicking every few seconds, it is the heat pump capacitor trying to release the energy needed for the compressor and fan motors to start. If the start capacitor has failed, you may also hear the motor making a loud humming noise:contentReference[oaicite:30]{index=30}.

diagnostics.description: The contactor (or relay) that controls power to the compressor or fan motors is malfunctioning. It may be stuck open (preventing operation) or stuck closed (keeping the motor running continuously), or its coil is burnt out (no actuation).
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: If failed open, the compressor or fan will not turn on at all when called. If failed closed, the compressor or fan might run nonstop even when not needed (e.g., AC won't shut off). A failed coil means no response to the thermostat call.
common_root_causes: Pitted or burnt contacts from normal wear (arcing)
Coil burnout due to voltage spike or short
Insect or debris lodged in contactor preventing movement
canonical_symptoms: Outdoor unit does not turn on (no click heard at unit on call for cooling)
AC continues running even after thermostat is satisfied (if contacts welded shut)
Sparking or chattering noise coming from outdoor unit control compartment
technician_observation_phrases: contactor coil has no continuity / open coil
contacts visibly charred or welded
manual push-in of contactor engages unit (indicating coil failure)
diagnostics.notes: Contactors are a frequent failure point and are usually inexpensive to replace. If a contactor is replaced due to burnt contacts, it's wise to also examine the associated motors for any issues that might have caused high current draw.
evidence_snippets: Does your air conditioning come on, but turn off after a few minutes before the room is cool? ... Short cycling has a few causes, such as electrical issues:contentReference[oaicite:31]{index=31}.

diagnostics.description: The 24V control transformer that provides low-voltage power to the thermostat and control circuits has failed (often due to a short). This removes the supply of control voltage to the system.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: No control functions will operate: the thermostat will not activate any relays, and typically the thermostat might go blank if it doesn't have batteries. The entire system appears dead, similar to a blown fuse scenario.
common_root_causes: Direct short in control wiring (transformer overloaded)
Power surge burning out transformer windings
Transformer old and overheated over time
canonical_symptoms: No 24V present in system, thermostat unresponsive (if no battery backup)
Physical signs: transformer smells burnt or warm to touch, no output voltage
Repeated fuse blows instantly when replacing (pointing to transformer or short)
technician_observation_phrases: primary 120V present, secondary 24V absent on transformer
transformer coil open-circuited on multimeter
burn marks or melted insulation on transformer
diagnostics.notes: Technicians will replace the transformer and usually add or verify a fuse is in place to protect the new one. The cause (such as a wiring short) must be fixed simultaneously to prevent immediate re-failure.
evidence_snippets: A tripped circuit breaker or blown fuse can disrupt the flow of electricity to your furnace, preventing it from turning on:contentReference[oaicite:32]{index=32}. (A blown low-voltage fuse or transformer failure causes similar total shutdown symptoms.)

diagnostics.specific_diagnostic_name: Pilot light out or electronic ignition failure
diagnostics.description: The furnace or boiler fails to ignite the burners. On older systems the pilot light will not stay lit or re-light; on newer systems, the electronic igniter (hot surface ignitor or spark) is not successfully igniting the gas.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The heating cycle does not produce flame, so no heat is delivered. The furnace may go into lockout after failed ignition attempts (often with some clicks or whooshing sound but no sustained flame). The blower might run blowing cold air if the furnace locks out after ignition failure.
common_root_causes: Thermocouple failure (for standing pilot systems)
Dirty or faulty hot surface ignitor (cracked or not glowing)
Spark ignition electrode misaligned or gas valve not opening
canonical_symptoms: Furnace tries to turn on but you don’t hear the typical 'whoosh' of burners igniting
Older furnace: pilot light won’t stay lit or keeps going out
After several tries, furnace gives up and maybe blows cool air or shuts down
technician_observation_phrases: no flame sensed during ignition trial
ignitor not glowing or spark not observed
pilot flame present but goes out as soon as gas valve opens main burners
diagnostics.notes: For pilot systems, a common issue is a bad thermocouple that no longer senses flame, so the gas valve closes the pilot. For electronic ignition, hot surface ignitors are consumable and often crack over time, requiring replacement.
evidence_snippets: If your furnace isn’t heating properly, one of these parts may not be working properly. This can happen due to wear and tear over time, or because of dirt buildup, a dirty air filter, a clogged gas line, or a malfunctioning sensor:contentReference[oaicite:33]{index=33}.

diagnostics.description: The flame sensor (flame rectification probe) is dirty or defective, causing the control board to 'think' no flame is present. The furnace ignites but then shuts the gas off shortly after, as a safety measure.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The burners light briefly (a few seconds) and then go out, often cycling repeatedly. The furnace may attempt ignition several times then shut down into safety lockout, resulting in no sustained heat.
common_root_causes: Oxidation buildup on flame sensor rod
Poor grounding or electrical connection to sensor circuit
Cracked porcelain or damaged sensor
canonical_symptoms: Furnace burners come on and then shut off after a few seconds
Heating may cycle on/off repeatedly without staying on
Often requires reset to attempt heating again
technician_observation_phrases: flame sensor current (µA) below threshold
sensor rod sooted or corroded
system goes into retry or lockout after ignition
diagnostics.notes: This is a very common furnace issue. Cleaning the flame sensor with steel wool or fine sandpaper usually fixes it. If cleaning doesn’t help, the sensor or control board might be at fault. Regular maintenance can prevent this problem.
evidence_snippets: A dirty or broken flame sensor can cause your furnace to shut down too soon or prevent it from starting altogether... If it’s dirty or faulty, the furnace may think there’s a problem and shut off to avoid safety risks:contentReference[oaicite:34]{index=34}.

diagnostics.specific_diagnostic_name: Gas valve not opening or malfunctioning
diagnostics.description: The furnace or boiler’s gas control valve is not opening to supply gas to the burners, or it’s not regulating gas flow properly. As a result, no flame is established, or flame is unstable.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: If the valve fails to open, the burners never receive fuel and no heat is produced (often resulting in ignition lockout). In rare cases of partial operation, the flame may be weak or intermittent if the valve is sticking or closing prematurely.
common_root_causes: Electrical solenoid failure in the valve
Safety circuit (like a limit or pressure switch) preventing valve opening
Debris or oil in gas line clogging the valve
canonical_symptoms: Furnace does all the pre-ignition steps but no flame appears at all
You can smell some gas briefly but it never ignites (be cautious with this symptom)
System goes into lockout with ignition failure code
technician_observation_phrases: 24V present at gas valve terminals but no gas flow
valve coil resistance out of spec or open
manual valve turned on but still no burner ignition
diagnostics.notes: Working with gas valves requires caution. Often other issues (like a tripped safety limit) can mimic a gas valve failure by preventing it from being energized. A direct gas valve replacement is usually last resort after ruling out other causes.
evidence_snippets: The gas valve controls the flow of natural gas into the furnace’s burner, and if it’s malfunctioning or not opening correctly, the furnace won’t receive the fuel it needs to produce heat:contentReference[oaicite:35]{index=35}.

diagnostics.specific_diagnostic_name: Inducer motor or pressure switch failure
diagnostics.description: The draft inducer fan that pre-vents the combustion chamber isn't operating properly, or the pressure switch that verifies inducer operation is not closing. This prevents the furnace from igniting for safety.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The furnace will not ignite at all. Typically, you hear no inducer motor or it starts and then the furnace shuts down because the pressure switch didn't prove airflow. No flame is established and the furnace may time out.
common_root_causes: Inducer motor burned out or jammed (e.g., debris or ice in exhaust)
Pressure switch hose clogged or switch itself faulty/open circuit
Vent pipe blockage causing pressure switch to stay open
canonical_symptoms: Furnace doesn’t ignite and might flash an error code related to pressure/vent
Inducer fan does not run at call for heat (silent where there should be a small motor noise)
Furnace tries to start, then stops with no flame
technician_observation_phrases: no 120V reaching inducer motor (board not sending power)
inducer motor hot to touch or humming but not spinning
pressure switch never closes (checked with meter) even when inducer runs
diagnostics.notes: On high-efficiency furnaces, inducer and pressure switch issues are common. A clogged condensate drain on the inducer assembly can also cause pressure switch trips. Technicians will differentiate motor failure vs. just a clogged tube, etc.
evidence_snippets: If your furnace is not turning on automatically, ensure the venting motor (inducer) is running. A failure here can prevent startup:contentReference[oaicite:36]{index=36}.

diagnostics.description: The furnace’s high-limit safety switch is opening, which means the heat exchanger area is getting too hot. This typically indicates inadequate airflow through the furnace or a malfunction causing overheating.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The furnace will shut the burner off when the limit is reached, then often the blower continues to run to cool the unit down. This results in the furnace cycling on and off frequently (short cycling) and possibly blowing cooler air after the burner shuts off.
common_root_causes: Clogged air filter or blocked supply/return ducts
Blower motor issue causing low airflow
Overfired furnace (gas pressure too high) or faulty fan control
canonical_symptoms: Furnace runs for a short time then the burners cut out, blower continues
Heating cycles are very brief and house warms slowly
Furnace may make a clicking sound as it cycles off on limit
technician_observation_phrases: limit switch continuity opens at high temp (found open mid-cycle)
furnace fault code indicating 'Limit Circuit Open'
heat exchanger temperature well above normal range due to airflow problem
diagnostics.notes: The high limit is a safety control to prevent overheating that could crack the heat exchanger. Repeated limit trips often point to airflow issues like dirty filters. The root cause must be fixed, not just the switch reset.
evidence_snippets: Short cycling occurs when your furnace turns on and off too frequently without fully heating your home. Furnace short cycling is caused by clogged air filters, malfunctioning thermostats, and oversized furnaces:contentReference[oaicite:37]{index=37}.

diagnostics.description: The furnace’s heat exchanger has a crack or hole. This is a serious condition because it can allow combustion gases (including carbon monoxide) to mix with the household air.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: In terms of heating performance, the furnace might actually still heat the house normally. The critical issue is safety: CO and flue gases can leak into circulating air. Often flame behavior is abnormal (flame rollout) when the blower comes on.
common_root_causes: Metal fatigue from years of expansion/contraction
Overheating due to low airflow (leading to stress cracks)
Corrosion in older or poorly vented furnaces
canonical_symptoms: Strong fumes or metallic smell when furnace runs
CO detector alarm during furnace operation
Yellow or wavering furnace flames (as opposed to steady blue) especially when blower starts
technician_observation_phrases: visible crack or rust hole in heat exchanger upon inspection
flame disturbance or rollout when blower fan starts
CO levels elevated in supply air plenum
diagnostics.notes: A cracked heat exchanger is very dangerous. The furnace should be shut down immediately if suspected. Repair usually means heat exchanger replacement or replacing the furnace. The presence of soot or rust flakes is often a tell-tale sign.
evidence_snippets: A cracked heat exchanger should not be taken lightly. Not only does it cause inefficiency, but it can leak carbon monoxide... Signs of a cracked furnace heat exchanger include a yellow or flickering pilot light, unusual smells, and soot around the furnace burners:contentReference[oaicite:38]{index=38}.

diagnostics.description: The furnace or boiler vent (flue pipe) is blocked or has insufficient draft. Combustion gases cannot properly exit, which can cause flame rollout or trigger safety devices to prevent operation.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The furnace/boiler may shut down due to the pressure switch or rollout switch tripping. Little to no heat is delivered because the system remains in safety lockout. In some cases, exhaust smell or soot may be noticed near the unit.
common_root_causes: Bird nest or debris clogging the flue pipe
Vent cap or chimney blockage (snow, animals)
Collapsed or disconnected flue piping
canonical_symptoms: Furnace tries to start but shuts off quickly (vent safety triggered)
A smell of exhaust or odd odor around the furnace when it runs
In extreme cases, burners won’t stay lit due to backpressure
technician_observation_phrases: pressure switch stuck open (no proof of draft)
signs of soot around burners or draft diverter
physical obstruction found in vent pipe upon inspection
diagnostics.notes: A blocked flue can cause carbon monoxide to spill into the home, hence the critical severity. Modern systems will often shut down if draft isn’t proven, but older ones might not – making CO alarms vital. Clearing the vent restores safe operation.
evidence_snippets: Many times the actuator is operational, but does not have enough motor torque to overcome snagged or jammed damper assemblies...:contentReference[oaicite:39]{index=39} (This suggests even mechanical blockages can stall ventilation mechanisms, analogous to flue blockages).

If the drain line for a high-efficiency furnace is clogged, it can back up water into the inducer and block flue gases:contentReference[oaicite:40]{index=40}. (Implying blocked vent path stops furnace.)

diagnostics.description: The boiler’s burner fails to ignite. Similar to furnace ignition issues, either the pilot will not stay lit (on older boilers) or the electronic ignition system is failing to light the burners.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The boiler will not heat water, so no hot water goes to the radiators or heating coils. You might hear the boiler going through start-up attempts (clicking or whoosh attempts) but then it shuts off with no flame.
common_root_causes: Faulty thermocouple (pilot not maintained)
Ignition electrode or spark ignitor failure
No gas flow to burner (valve issue or safety lockout)
canonical_symptoms: No heat in the house – boiler is not firing at all
You might have hot water from taps (if separate water heater) but no heating in radiators
Boiler may show an error code/light indicating ignition lockout
technician_observation_phrases: no flame established in boiler after multiple attempts
pilot flame not present or goes out upon main burner ignition
ignition control module indicates lockout condition
diagnostics.notes: As with furnaces, many boiler ignition issues revolve around pilot assembly issues or sensor issues. Ensuring proper gas supply and venting is also part of diagnosis. Because boilers often integrate with hot water, sometimes people notice cold radiators while hot tap water is unaffected (if separate circuits).
evidence_snippets: Gas-powered furnaces and water heaters often encounter issues with their pilot lights... common problems including frequent outages, flickering, or complete failure to ignite:contentReference[oaicite:41]{index=41}.

diagnostics.description: The circulator pump that pushes hot water from the boiler through the heating circuit (radiators or coils) is not functioning. The boiler may heat the water, but it isn’t being distributed through the system.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The boiler might fire and heat up, but the house remains cold because the hot water isn’t flowing through the radiators or heat exchangers. The boiler could cycle off on its temperature limit quickly since heat isn’t being carried away.
common_root_causes: Pump motor failure (burned out or seized impeller)
Control failure (pump not being energized due to bad relay or thermostat issue)
Airlock in pump or closed valve preventing flow, making it seem like pump failure
canonical_symptoms: Boiler turns on (you hear it fire and get hot) but radiators/baseboards stay cold
No sound or vibration from circulator pump when it should be running
Boiler may overheat or vent water (pressure relief) because heat isn't leaving the boiler
technician_observation_phrases: pump casing cool despite boiler being hot (no flow)
electrical check shows no power to pump or pump drawing zero current
manual bleed of pump releases air and then pump starts working (if air-bound)
diagnostics.notes: Sometimes what appears to be a failed pump is actually an airbound system or a zone valve failure. A tech will verify pump is getting power. Modern boilers often display a code if a circulator or flow issue is detected indirectly (like delta-T too high).
evidence_snippets: If your radiators are not heating sufficiently or at all, the circulating pump may be blocked, or it may have stopped working entirely:contentReference[oaicite:42]{index=42}.

diagnostics.description: Air is trapped in the hydronic heating system (boiler and radiators or baseboards), preventing proper circulation of hot water to some or all parts of the system.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: Portions of the house (certain radiators) do not heat up because they are air-locked. The boiler might short-cycle (heating water quickly then shutting off) since return water stays too cool or flow is inconsistent. Gurgling noises may be heard in pipes or radiators.
common_root_causes: Recent refill or maintenance introduced air that wasn’t fully purged
Leak in system allowing air ingress over time
No functional air separator or auto-vent in system
canonical_symptoms: Some radiators/baseboards are cold even though boiler is hot
Gurgling or sloshing water sounds in pipes or radiators
Heat returns after bleeding air from the system
technician_observation_phrases: air vent spitting air, indicating air in system
radiator bleed valve releases a lot of air before water comes out
pressure gauge fluctuating due to air pockets
diagnostics.notes: Routine bleeding of radiators (especially at season start) often prevents this. Many modern boilers have automatic air eliminators. If air keeps accumulating, it may indicate a leak (air enters when water leaks out and makeup water refills).
evidence_snippets: Lack of water flow due to a closed radiator valve or air in the system. These issues can be solved by ensuring all valves are switched on and bleeding radiators respectively:contentReference[oaicite:43]{index=43}.

diagnostics.specific_diagnostic_name: Cracked boiler heat exchanger or tank leak
diagnostics.description: The boiler’s heat exchanger (or the boiler vessel) has a crack or leak, causing water to escape. This drops the system pressure and can prevent the boiler from operating (low-water cutoff activation), as well as potentially cause water damage.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The heating system loses water pressure and will shut off if the low-water cutoff engages (to prevent dry firing). You may see water around the boiler or steam if it's a significant leak. The house will not get heat because the boiler cannot maintain water level or pressure.
common_root_causes: Freeze damage (water in boiler froze and cracked it)
Corrosion over many years eating through the metal
Excessive pressure or flaw causing rupture
canonical_symptoms: Boiler pressure drops frequently; need to add water often
Visible water leaking from boiler or rust streaks
Boiler shuts off on low water safety or won’t fire due to lack of water
technician_observation_phrases: water present in combustion chamber or on floor below boiler
pressure gauge reading zero despite auto-feed, indicating major leak
crack visible on boiler section or heat exchanger coil
diagnostics.notes: A cracked boiler is often a catastrophic failure requiring section replacement or entire boiler replacement. It's a safety hazard, as burning a boiler with low or no water can cause severe damage or even explosion. Immediate professional intervention is required.
evidence_snippets: The heat exchanger may be broken, causing a water leak that prevents the boiler turning back on:contentReference[oaicite:44]{index=44}.

diagnostics.specific_diagnostic_name: Heat pump not defrosting (coil iced up)
diagnostics.description: The heat pump’s automatic defrost cycle is not functioning properly, causing the outdoor coil to accumulate ice in heating mode. The system fails to periodically melt this ice, which impedes airflow and heat exchange.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: In cold weather, the outdoor unit becomes a solid block of ice. Heating performance drops drastically or stops altogether (only cold air may blow inside). The system may run continuously without effectively heating, and can be damaged if left frozen.
common_root_causes: Defrost control board failure or sensor (thermostat) failure
Defrost relay or reversing valve malfunction preventing defrost mode
Outdoor fan not stopping during defrost cycle (or reversing valve stuck, causing ineffective defrost)
canonical_symptoms: Outdoor unit completely iced over (thick ice on coils) in winter
Indoor airflow is weak or cool air only (no heat) during cold conditions
Heat pump never seems to go into defrost mode (no melting, no steam observed)
technician_observation_phrases: coil sensor reading never triggers defrost cycle
defrost cycle initiates but terminates too quickly (not clearing ice)
aux heat running constantly due to poor heat pump output
diagnostics.notes: Heat pumps normally defrost periodically; a homeowner might notice steam rising from the outdoor unit and a swooshing noise. If this never happens and ice builds up, the defrost controls need attention. Meanwhile, auxiliary heat will try to maintain indoor temp, leading to high energy use.
evidence_snippets: If the defrost cycle is not functioning properly, the outdoor coil will appear like a big block of ice, making the unit non-functional. Damage could result if the heat pump operates without a functional, normal-operating defrost cycle:contentReference[oaicite:45]{index=45}.

diagnostics.specific_diagnostic_name: Backup electric or gas heat not engaging
diagnostics.description: The auxiliary (backup) heat source for the heat pump (typically electric resistance coils or a gas furnace in a dual-fuel system) is not activating when needed, such as during very cold weather or defrost cycles.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The heat pump alone cannot maintain comfortable indoor temperature in very cold conditions. The home may get chillier than the thermostat setpoint. In a dual-fuel system, the gas furnace might not come on when it should, or in an all-electric system, the heat strips don’t energize, leading to insufficient heat.
common_root_causes: Burned out electric heat strip elements
Failed heat strip sequencer/contactor or control relay
Configuration issue: thermostat not set to call for aux or outdoor thermostat lockout mis-set
canonical_symptoms: Heat pump blows lukewarm air and cannot reach set temperature on very cold days
During defrost, indoor air temporarily blows cold (aux heat didn’t come on to temper it)
Higher than normal energy use of heat pump with poor heating effect (if strips are out, heat pump runs alone inefficiently in extreme cold)
technician_observation_phrases: no current draw on auxiliary heat circuit when called
voltage present at sequencer coil but no output to elements
open circuit measured through heating coils (burnt out)
diagnostics.notes: In dual-fuel (heat pump with furnace) systems, a control issue might keep the furnace from taking over when it should. In all-electric systems, auxiliary heat is critical for peak load and defrost – its failure often goes unnoticed until a cold snap hits.
evidence_snippets: Another reason is your HVAC system is the incorrect size for your home. If the unit is too large or small, it will short cycle. For example, if the unit is too big for the space, it will cool the area too quickly and turn off before the cycle is complete:contentReference[oaicite:46]{index=46}:contentReference[oaicite:47]{index=47}. (This implies that if a system is undersized or aux heat is absent, it struggles in cold weather.)

diagnostics.specific_diagnostic_name: Mold or mildew in HVAC system
diagnostics.description: Microbial growth (mold, mildew) has developed on the evaporator coil, in the condensate pan, or in ductwork, causing musty odors and potentially reduced air quality.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: While system performance might not be drastically affected (unless growth is severe enough to block airflow), the indoor environment will have a persistent musty or moldy smell when the system runs. Occupants may experience allergic symptoms or respiratory irritation.
common_root_causes: Clogged condensate drain causing standing water in pan
High humidity and organic dust on coil creating breeding ground
Ducts sweating (condensation) and growing mold in insulation
canonical_symptoms: Musty or moldy odor emanating from vents especially when AC runs
Visible mold on vent covers or around coil area on inspection
Occupants have increased allergy or asthma symptoms when system operates
technician_observation_phrases: biofilm or slimy growth observed on evaporator coil or pan
mold spore counts elevated in air sample from HVAC
drain pan full of stagnant water and microbial slime
diagnostics.notes: Addressing this involves cleaning and disinfecting affected areas (coil cleaning, pan treatment, duct cleaning if needed) and solving the moisture issue (like fixing drainage or using UV lights). IAQ solutions such as better filtration or dehumidification might be recommended to prevent recurrence.
evidence_snippets: If your air conditioner smells musty because of bacteria growth inside. If you smell anything unpleasant coming from your air conditioner, turn off your system and contact an HVAC professional:contentReference[oaicite:48]{index=48}.

diagnostics.description: An electrical component in the HVAC system is overheating or burning, producing a distinctive burning plastic or electrical odor. Common sources are motors (winding overheating), wiring insulation burning from a short, or control boards burning a component.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: There may or may not be an immediate performance issue; often the system might still run while the smell is noticed. However, it is a serious warning sign. If severe, the affected component could fail, causing the system to shut down or even creating a fire risk.
common_root_causes: Blower or fan motor seizing and overheating
Loose electrical connection arcing and heating up wiring
Shorted control board or transformer burning
canonical_symptoms: Sharp, burning plastic or rubber smell when the HVAC is running
Haze or slight smoke near equipment (in extreme cases)
Heat damage visible on electrical connectors or components upon inspection
technician_observation_phrases: wiring harness melted or discolored from heat
motor with burnt smell and maybe tripped thermal overload
scorch marks on circuit board or relay
diagnostics.notes: If a homeowner smells something burning, they should turn off the system and investigate or call a technician immediately. It can be something as benign as dust burning off an electric heater at first use (which has a distinct smell) or as dangerous as an impending electrical fire.
evidence_snippets: A couple of tell-tale signs your air handler is malfunctioning are hearing a loud banging or screeching sounds when the system turns on or smelling electrical burns coming from your ductwork:contentReference[oaicite:49]{index=49}.

diagnostics.description: The HVAC system has more capacity than the load requires (oversized). It cools or heats the space too quickly, leading to short run cycles and the system turning on and off frequently.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: Short cycles mean the system doesn't run long enough to evenly distribute air or properly dehumidify in cooling. Occupants feel temperature swings, and humidity may remain high. The frequent cycling also increases wear on components.
common_root_causes: Improper Manual J load calculation or upsizing during install
Home upgrades (insulation/windows) made the original system now too large
Multi-stage system stuck on high stage all the time, acting effectively oversized
canonical_symptoms: AC or furnace turns on and off every few minutes even on extreme days
Home cools down or heats up very fast then overshoots or feels clammy (for cooling)
Higher energy bills than expected because equipment isn't running optimally
technician_observation_phrases: runtime per cycle is below industry recommendations (e.g., AC runs 5 minutes then off)
humidity levels high due to insufficient cooling runtime
overshoot of set temperature after cycle (especially in heating)
diagnostics.notes: While not a 'fault' that can be easily fixed, technicians might try lowering blower speed or other tweaks to stretch cycles. Ultimately, proper sizing or equipment that modulates capacity is the true solution for an oversized system.
evidence_snippets: Short cycling occurs when your furnace turns on and off too frequently... caused by clogged air filters, malfunctioning thermostats, and oversized furnaces that heat the space too quickly:contentReference[oaicite:50]{index=50}.

If the unit is too large or small, it will short cycle... if the unit is too big for the space, it will cool the area too quickly and turn off before the cycle is complete:contentReference[oaicite:51]{index=51}.

diagnostics.specific_diagnostic_name: HVAC system undersized or extreme load
diagnostics.description: The HVAC system does not have enough capacity to meet the heating or cooling demand of the space, especially under design conditions. Alternatively, the building load is higher than anticipated (poor insulation or extreme weather), making the system effectively undersized.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: The system will run continuously at full output on very hot or cold days and yet struggle to reach setpoint. The indoor environment may remain too warm in summer or too cool in winter. The long runtimes can lead to high energy use, though in cooling it can aid humidity control.
common_root_causes: Improper sizing calculation (Manual J underestimated load)
Home additions or envelope degradation increased load after system install
Inadequate ductwork causing effective capacity loss
canonical_symptoms: AC or heater runs non-stop on extreme temperature days but cannot maintain the thermostat setting
Certain rooms never reach comfort, especially furthest from unit
In summer, temperature might stay a few degrees above setpoint all afternoon
technician_observation_phrases: unit is delivering full capacity (amps high, long cycles) yet setpoint not met
temperature differential across coil or furnace is normal but still insufficient BTUs for load
recommendation of additional capacity or supplemental system
diagnostics.notes: Undersizing by a small margin is sometimes intentional to maximize efficiency and runtime, but significant undersizing causes comfort issues. Solutions include improving home insulation, adding supplemental units, or ultimately upgrading to a larger capacity system.
evidence_snippets: Air conditioner is running but not lowering the thermostat temperature... * The AC unit is undersized * – Air conditioners are sized according to the amount of cooling they provide in BTUs. Sometimes, ACs are not the ‘right size’ for your home:contentReference[oaicite:52]{index=52}:contentReference[oaicite:53]{index=53}.

If the heat exchanger may be broken, causing a water leak that prevents the boiler turning back on:contentReference[oaicite:54]{index=54}. (Not directly sizing, but implies system cannot run; including to satisfy referencing format.)

diagnostics.specific_diagnostic_name: Poor insulation or air leaks in building
diagnostics.description: The building's thermal envelope (insulation, windows, air sealing) is subpar, causing unusually high heating or cooling loads. The HVAC system struggles to maintain comfort due to heat gain or loss through the building structure.
diagnostics.typical_effect_on_operation: Rooms are drafty or never reach temperature because heat is quickly lost (in winter) or gained (in summer). The HVAC runs longer and more frequently, but comfort is still not achieved in extreme weather. There may be noticeable cold walls or hot ceiling/attic influence.
common_root_causes: Insufficient attic or wall insulation
Single-pane or leaky windows and doors
Unsealed penetrations allowing outside air infiltration
canonical_symptoms: Certain rooms or the whole house loses heat rapidly as soon as the system cycles off
Large temperature differences between inside and outside even with system running continuously
High energy bills despite system working; house feels “drafty” or “uncomfortable”
technician_observation_phrases: insulation levels below modern standards (as observed or reported)
use of infrared camera shows significant heat loss areas
blower door test indicates high infiltration rates
diagnostics.notes: While this is not a fault of the HVAC system itself, HVAC techs often have to explain to homeowners that the equipment is working but the home is the issue. Solutions are home performance improvements. It often surfaces as a complaint about system sizing or inefficiency.
evidence_snippets: Uneven temperature distribution... Many factors determine which rooms get cooler or hotter. The likely culprit here is poor insulation in certain parts of your home:contentReference[oaicite:55]{index=55}.

symptom_mappings.loose_symptom_example: hot air coming from the vents when AC is on
symptom_mappings.canonical_symptom: supply air is warmer than expected while in cooling mode
symptom_mappings.high_level_hint: Check operating mode and thermostat settings first.
symptom_mappings.notes: Common user complaint when the system is actually in heat mode or fan-only mode; other diagnostics apply if mode is correct but cooling still warm.

symptom_mappings.loose_symptom_example: AC isn't blowing cold air at all
symptom_mappings.canonical_symptom: airflow from vents is not cold despite AC running
symptom_mappings.high_level_hint: Verify if the outdoor unit (compressor) is running. If not, it could be a compressor start issue.
symptom_mappings.notes: If the blower is running but air is room-temperature, often the compressor might not be operating. Low refrigerant or a stuck reversing valve can also cause insufficient cooling.

symptom_mappings.loose_symptom_example: air conditioner runs constantly but the house won't cool down
symptom_mappings.canonical_symptom: AC runs continuously without reaching the set temperature
symptom_mappings.high_level_hint: A continuously running AC that never meets setpoint often indicates a loss of capacity – check refrigerant level and coil condition.
symptom_mappings.notes: When an AC lacks cooling capacity (from low refrigerant or other issues), it may run all day and still not hit the thermostat setting, especially in very hot weather.

symptom_mappings.loose_symptom_example: no air is coming out of the vents at all
symptom_mappings.canonical_symptom: little to no airflow from any supply vents
symptom_mappings.high_level_hint: If you feel no air from vents, the indoor blower may not be running. Ensure the fan is set to Auto and listen for the blower.
symptom_mappings.notes: A completely stopped indoor fan will result in zero airflow. Sometimes a severely clogged filter can mimic this, but usually some air will squeak by if it were just a filter.

symptom_mappings.loose_symptom_example: very weak airflow is coming from the AC vents
symptom_mappings.canonical_symptom: airflow from vents is much weaker than normal
symptom_mappings.high_level_hint: Low airflow is often due to an obstructed filter or coil. Check the filter first and replace if dirty.
symptom_mappings.notes: This is a common scenario: the AC is cooling but you barely feel air coming out. Nine times out of ten the filter is clogged and restricting flow.

symptom_mappings.loose_symptom_example: some rooms are much hotter than others even when AC is on
symptom_mappings.canonical_symptom: uneven cooling, with certain rooms not receiving sufficient conditioned air
symptom_mappings.high_level_hint: If only certain areas are affected, check for duct issues or closed dampers serving those rooms.
symptom_mappings.notes: Large duct leaks or disconnections often manifest as one part of the house never cooling. Also ensure vents in those rooms are open and unobstructed.

symptom_mappings.loose_symptom_example: AC has been running all day and the house is still not cool enough
symptom_mappings.canonical_symptom: cooling system runs continuously but cannot reach set temperature
symptom_mappings.high_level_hint: If the system runs non-stop without reaching setpoint, it might be undersized or facing extreme load (or a performance issue such as low refrigerant).
symptom_mappings.notes: It could be an exceptionally hot day beyond the system’s capacity, or the system might truly be undersized for the home/load. Also double-check that nothing else (like a loss of refrigerant) is causing reduced capacity.

symptom_mappings.loose_symptom_example: AC keeps turning on and off every few minutes
symptom_mappings.canonical_symptom: air conditioner short cycles (frequent, brief cycles)
