symptom_mappings.high_level_hint: Frequent short cycling often points to an oversized system or a control issue. Ensure thermostat placement is good and unit size is appropriate.
symptom_mappings.notes: This behavior reduces efficiency and can be hard on the compressor. Oversized AC units are a prime cause, but sometimes a thermostat with poor placement (near supply vent, for example) can also cause rapid cycling.

symptom_mappings.loose_symptom_example: thermostat is set to cool but the air is room temperature
symptom_mappings.canonical_symptom: no noticeable cooling effect when AC is running
symptom_mappings.high_level_hint: If everything runs but air isn’t cold, the system might be low on refrigerant or have lost its cooling capacity. Check for ice on the lines or coil.
symptom_mappings.notes: The system could be running with a significantly reduced charge and thus only producing mildly cool air. A professional should measure pressures and check for leaks.

symptom_mappings.loose_symptom_example: AC won't turn on at all
symptom_mappings.canonical_symptom: no response or activity from AC system when cooling is called
symptom_mappings.high_level_hint: If the system is entirely dead, check the breaker and any emergency switches first. Also ensure the thermostat has power.
symptom_mappings.notes: Total non-operation is often a power supply problem. It’s good to verify the thermostat settings and power. If those are okay, a blown fuse on the furnace control board is another likely cause.

symptom_mappings.loose_symptom_example: outdoor AC unit is humming but the fan isn't spinning
symptom_mappings.canonical_symptom: outdoor condenser unit makes a humming sound but fan is not running
symptom_mappings.high_level_hint: A humming outdoor unit with a stationary fan often indicates a bad fan capacitor or motor issue. Turn off power to avoid overheating and have it checked.
symptom_mappings.notes: This classic symptom usually means the fan’s capacitor can’t start the motor. Sometimes you’ll also find the compressor humming (trying to run) which can overheat if the fan doesn’t start.

symptom_mappings.loose_symptom_example: circuit breaker keeps tripping whenever the AC tries to start
symptom_mappings.canonical_symptom: electrical breaker trip on AC startup
symptom_mappings.high_level_hint: Repeated breaker trips often indicate a short or a motor drawing locked-rotor amps. A failed compressor or fan motor could be at fault.
symptom_mappings.notes: It’s important not to keep resetting the breaker repeatedly without addressing the cause. A seized compressor is a common cause; if that’s the case, the compressor may need replacement or further diagnostics (like checking capacitance or a hard start kit).

symptom_mappings.loose_symptom_example: there is ice all over the indoor coil and refrigerant pipes
symptom_mappings.canonical_symptom: evaporator coil or suction line is covered in ice during cooling
symptom_mappings.high_level_hint: Frost on the coil is usually due to either low airflow or low refrigerant. Check that the filter is clean and airflow is sufficient first.
symptom_mappings.notes: The first step in thawing an iced coil is to turn off the AC and let it melt, then address the cause. Very often, a dirty filter or coil is to blame. If not, a technician will measure refrigerant charge and other factors.

symptom_mappings.loose_symptom_example: the heat pump outside is completely encased in ice
symptom_mappings.canonical_symptom: outdoor heat pump unit is fully iced up in heating mode
symptom_mappings.high_level_hint: If the entire outdoor unit is a block of ice, the defrost cycle likely isn’t working. Switch to emergency heat and get the defrost system checked.
symptom_mappings.notes: A thin layer of frost is normal before defrost, but a thick ice buildup indicates a problem. Continuing to run the heat pump in this state can damage it, so one should use backup heat until it’s fixed.

symptom_mappings.loose_symptom_example: heat pump is on heating mode but blowing cold or cool air
symptom_mappings.canonical_symptom: heat pump provides insufficient warmth in heating mode
symptom_mappings.high_level_hint: If a heat pump isn't delivering heat, ensure it's not stuck in cooling. The reversing valve or the auxiliary heat might be at fault.
symptom_mappings.notes: Sometimes homeowners mistake the cooler air from a heat pump (compared to a furnace) as a problem. But truly blowing cold air means a malfunction. Confirm the outdoor unit isn’t iced up and that the thermostat hasn’t disabled aux heat.

symptom_mappings.loose_symptom_example: the house won't warm up on very cold days, heat pump seems to run but it's chilly
symptom_mappings.canonical_symptom: heat pump struggles to heat on cold days (insufficient heating)
symptom_mappings.high_level_hint: In very cold weather, heat pumps rely on auxiliary heat. If the home stays cold, the backup heat may not be kicking in or the heat pump might be undersized for extreme cold.
symptom_mappings.notes: Homeowners might not realize that below a certain temperature, the heat pump alone can't maintain setpoint without help. If auxiliary heat is electric and not working, the heat pump will run continuously with little effect as temps drop.

symptom_mappings.loose_symptom_example: my energy bills are much higher than usual and the AC runs a lot
symptom_mappings.canonical_symptom: significantly higher energy consumption for heating/cooling
symptom_mappings.high_level_hint: Higher bills with constant system operation can indicate lost efficiency. A low refrigerant level (leak) often causes longer runtimes and higher energy use.
symptom_mappings.notes: Whenever bills spike without a change in weather or thermostat settings, it's worth checking system performance. Low refrigerant reduces cooling capacity and efficiency, so the system runs longer to do the same job.

symptom_mappings.loose_symptom_example: carbon monoxide detector goes off when the furnace is running
symptom_mappings.canonical_symptom: CO alarm triggers during furnace operation
symptom_mappings.high_level_hint: A CO alarm is a serious warning. Turn off the furnace immediately. A cracked heat exchanger or venting problem could be allowing combustion gases into the home.
symptom_mappings.notes: CO alarm activation is life-safety critical. Even if the furnace appears to be heating fine, do not use it until it's inspected. Technicians will check for cracks and test CO levels. Vent blockages can also cause CO buildup.

symptom_mappings.loose_symptom_example: there's a strong musty smell whenever the AC is running
symptom_mappings.canonical_symptom: musty or moldy odor emanating from HVAC when in operation
symptom_mappings.high_level_hint: A musty smell usually indicates mold or mildew in the system. Check the evaporator coil and condensate pan for growth and ensure the condensate drains properly.
symptom_mappings.notes: Musty smells can also arise from damp ducts or a dirty filter, but commonly the evaporator coil and drain are culprits. Cleaning the system and improving filtration/UV treatment can remedy and prevent mold issues.

symptom_mappings.loose_symptom_example: water is leaking from around the indoor unit
symptom_mappings.canonical_symptom: water pooling or dripping near indoor air handler/furnace
symptom_mappings.high_level_hint: Water around the unit indicates a condensate drainage problem. The drain line may be clogged, causing the pan to overflow.
symptom_mappings.notes: A clogged drain can often be cleared with vacuum or cleaning the trap. If the evaporator was a block of ice that melted, that could also cause a one-time leak – but often the root cause of that ice is also poor drainage or low airflow.

symptom_mappings.loose_symptom_example: the furnace is blowing cold air
symptom_mappings.canonical_symptom: air from furnace vents is not heated (cool air during heating mode)
symptom_mappings.high_level_hint: If the furnace blower is on but air is cold, the burners likely aren’t igniting. Check if the pilot is lit or if there's an ignition fault code.
symptom_mappings.notes: Sometimes after repeated ignition failures, the furnace will run just the blower to dissipate any residual gas or heat – which feels like cold air to occupants. This is a safety lockout mode.

symptom_mappings.loose_symptom_example: the furnace starts then shuts off after a few seconds
symptom_mappings.canonical_symptom: furnace ignites burners briefly then turns them off (short burn cycle)
symptom_mappings.high_level_hint: Burners that fire then shut down often mean the flame sensor isn’t detecting flame. Cleaning or replacing the flame sensor may solve the issue.
symptom_mappings.notes: Many modern furnaces will do exactly this when the flame sensor is dirty: light up, then kill the burners after ~2-3 seconds due to “no flame sensed”. They will retry a few times. During that time, the blower may not yet be on, or might start and blow lukewarm air.

symptom_mappings.loose_symptom_example: furnace keeps turning on and off quickly
symptom_mappings.canonical_symptom: furnace short cycles (rapid on/off cycling)
symptom_mappings.high_level_hint: Furnace short cycling is often due to overheating from low airflow. Make sure the filter is clean and that supply vents are open.
symptom_mappings.notes: In addition to a dirty filter, check if any vents or returns are blocked, and verify the blower motor is functioning properly. Once airflow issues are resolved, the furnace should run longer, steadier cycles.

symptom_mappings.loose_symptom_example: furnace won't turn on at all
symptom_mappings.canonical_symptom: no response from furnace (no heat) when heat is called
symptom_mappings.high_level_hint: For a completely dead furnace, ensure the furnace switch is on and the breaker is not tripped. Also check if the thermostat has power.
symptom_mappings.notes: Many furnaces have an emergency cutoff switch (often looks like a light switch on or near the unit). Homeowners sometimes inadvertently turn it off. After verifying power, a tech would look into control faults if the unit still doesn’t start any sequence at all.

symptom_mappings.loose_symptom_example: pilot light won't stay lit on my furnace
symptom_mappings.canonical_symptom: pilot light repeatedly goes out or fails to stay lit
symptom_mappings.high_level_hint: If a standing pilot won't stay lit, the thermocouple could be bad or there may be a draft issue. It’s often a thermocouple replacement if the flame goes out as soon as you release the pilot button.
symptom_mappings.notes: This applies to older furnaces/boilers with standing pilots. Newer systems have electronic ignition and no pilot. If the pilot won’t light at all, ensure gas supply is on. If it lights but won’t stay, thermocouple is suspect. If it stays but main burner never comes on, that's a gas valve or control issue.

symptom_mappings.loose_symptom_example: there's a strong electrical burning smell from the vents
symptom_mappings.canonical_symptom: burning plastic/electrical odor noticeable when HVAC operates
symptom_mappings.high_level_hint: An electrical burning smell indicates something in the system is overheating. Turn it off and inspect. Common causes include blower motor overheating or wiring issues.
symptom_mappings.notes: It's crucial to not ignore this smell. Sometimes a failing motor will emit this odor before it actually fails completely. Also check for any melted wires or components. Dust on electric heat strips can smell too, but that’s more of a dusty/burnt hair smell and usually only for a short time on first use.

symptom_mappings.loose_symptom_example: water is dripping from a ceiling vent
symptom_mappings.canonical_symptom: water staining or dripping from supply vent (especially one under attic unit)
symptom_mappings.high_level_hint: Water near a ceiling vent likely comes from an attic or upper-floor air handler. The condensate drain might be clogged, causing overflow. Check the drip pan and drain line.
symptom_mappings.notes: In many attic installations, there's an overflow pan under the unit tied to that ceiling vent. If water is dripping, the primary drain probably clogged and the overflow pan filled up – often the pan has a float switch to shut off the system, but if not or it failed, you'll see leaks.

symptom_mappings.loose_symptom_example: the furnace makes a loud bang when it starts up
symptom_mappings.canonical_symptom: loud banging or boom noise at furnace ignition
symptom_mappings.high_level_hint: A boom on startup usually means delayed ignition (gas builds up before igniting). This could be due to dirty burners or a weak ignition source. It should be addressed to avoid damage.
symptom_mappings.notes: This is commonly known as 'ignition roll-out' or 'delayed ignition'. Over time, it can crack the heat exchanger or damage the vent. Cleaning the burners and flame sensor, and ensuring proper gas pressure and igniter function, is important.

symptom_mappings.loose_symptom_example: there's a high-pitched squealing noise when the furnace runs
symptom_mappings.canonical_symptom: squealing or screeching sound during furnace blower operation
symptom_mappings.high_level_hint: Squealing from a furnace often comes from the blower assembly. It could be dry or worn motor bearings or a slipping belt (in older units with belt-driven blowers).
symptom_mappings.notes: If it’s a belt-driven blower (older furnace), the belt might be loose or the blower wheel could be rubbing. If direct-drive, likely the motor bearings. In either case, it's wise to shut it off to prevent a complete failure or overheating.

symptom_mappings.loose_symptom_example: the outdoor AC unit is making a buzzing sound but the compressor doesn't kick in
symptom_mappings.canonical_symptom: outdoor unit only buzzes (compressor not starting)
symptom_mappings.high_level_hint: A loud buzz with no compressor start typically indicates the compressor’s capacitor is bad or the compressor is stuck. This sound is the compressor trying to start unsuccessfully.
symptom_mappings.notes: This scenario often precedes a breaker trip if the thermal overload doesn't protect it in time. A capacitor replacement is the first thing to try. If that doesn’t fix it, the compressor may be seized or have an internal electrical problem.

source_index.title: HVAC Diagnostic Chart: What You Need to Know
source_index.notes: ServiceTitan blog article covering common HVAC issues and the use of diagnostic charts, includes explanations for electrical, refrigerant, and airflow problems.

source_index.title: Air Conditioner Troubleshooting: Why Your AC Is Not Cooling
source_index.notes: Trane residential troubleshooting guide listing common AC not cooling issues such as dirty coils, thermostat settings, refrigerant leaks, etc., with user-friendly advice.

source_index.title: AC Short Cycling – Causes and What to Do
source_index.notes: Trane educational content about what short cycling is, why it happens (thermostat issues or improper sizing), and its effects on comfort and energy.

source_index.title: Heat Pump Capacitor: What You Need to Know
source_index.notes: Trane article explaining the role of capacitors in heat pumps and ACs, and symptoms of a failing capacitor (e.g., unit won’t turn on, clicking but not running, fan not spinning, burning smell).

source_index.title: Heat Pump Reversing Valve Basics
source_index.notes: Trane resource describing how reversing valves work and signs of a problem (unit stuck in one mode, not heating or cooling when it should, strange noises during mode change).

source_index.title: 10 Most Common Furnace Repairs
source_index.notes: American Standard blog post outlining common furnace issues like clogged filters, short cycling, ignition problems, strange noises, cracked heat exchangers, thermostat issues, blower problems, flame sensor issues, electrical issues, and gas valve problems.

source_index.title: Your AC Isn’t Blowing Cold Air – Causes and Solutions
source_index.notes: Lennox consumer-facing article listing reasons an AC might not blow cold air, including clogged filters, dirty coils, thermostat issues, low refrigerant, duct problems, electrical issues, blocked vents, or an aging system.

source_index.title: 11 Common HVAC Problems and Solutions
source_index.notes: Angi (formerly Angie's List) article covering common HVAC issues: unit not turning on, poor airflow, uneven temperatures, strange noises, dirty coils, blowing hot air, refrigerant leaks, air handler malfunctions, short cycling, pilot light issues, and high energy bills.

source_index.title: Automated Fault Detection & Diagnostics for Rooftop Packaged Air Conditioners (Case Study)
source_index.notes: Technical case study outlining common RTU (rooftop unit) faults and their impacts, including low airflow, coil fouling, refrigerant charge faults, non-condensables, restrictions, short cycling, economizer faults, and their effect on efficiency and operation.

source_index.title: Defrost Cycle of a Heat Pump
source_index.publisher: InterNACHI (International Association of Certified Home Inspectors)
source_index.notes: InterNACHI educational article explaining how heat pump defrost cycles work and what happens if they don’t. Notably mentions that if defrost fails, the outdoor unit will become a block of ice and the unit will be non-functional.

source_index.title: Office Air Feels Stale? Your HVAC Might Be to Blame
source_index.notes: HVAC contractor blog discussing causes of stuffy, stale office air. Highlights poor ventilation (not enough fresh air), dirty filters, poor circulation, humidity issues, etc., and how these lead to heavy, uncomfortable air.

source_index.title: Heat Only Boiler Troubleshooting Guide
source_index.notes: UK-based boiler manufacturer guide that covers common boiler issues: boiler switching off (due to leaks or air), burners turning off (oversizing/modulation), pilot light issues, etc. Provides insight on causes like broken heat exchangers or air in system.

source_index.title: Lennox Furnace Troubleshooting - HVAC.com
source_index.notes: A troubleshooting guide (third-party) for Lennox furnaces, covering basics like checking power switches, thermostat, breakers, filter, etc., for a furnace that is not heating or blowing hot air.

source_index.title: Lennox Air Conditioner Troubleshooting: How to Fix
source_index.notes: Online guide listing common reasons an AC won’t turn on, like tripped breakers, thermostat issues, clogged filter, refrigerant issues, etc., geared towards Lennox but applicable generally.

source_index.title: Economizer Help - HVAC-Talk Forum Thread
source_index.notes: An online discussion among HVAC professionals about economizer issues. References how dampers can get stuck or actuators lack torque if dampers are jammed, etc. Provides insight into economizer faults.

source_index.title: Top 10 Most Common HVAC Issues and How to Prevent Them
source_index.notes: HVAC contractor blog listing common issues. For example, mentions symptom of hearing outdoor unit but no indoor airflow (sign of blower issue). General resource echoing common problems like motor failures.

source_index.title: 6 Most Common Furnace Problems
source_index.notes: Lists common furnace problems such as no heat, short cycling, not turning on, constant running, noisy operation, leaking water, etc. Hints at inducer and pressure switch issues under not turning on automatically.

source_index.title: Boiler Pump Not Working – Causes and How to Fix It
source_index.notes: Explains that if radiators are not heating, the circulator pump could be blocked or not running. A helpful resource on diagnosing circulator pump issues.

source_index.title: Automated Fault Detection and Diagnosis in Light Commercial Buildings (HVAC Fault Taxonomy)
source_index.publisher: Concordia University Research (Arash Shoukas et al.)
source_index.notes: Research paper outlining an HVAC fault taxonomy, includes mention that many faults produce similar symptoms and highlights sensor faults, communication faults, etc. It reinforces the challenge of fault diagnosis when multiple issues present similarly.
